questions.text: A patient with squamous cell carcinoma of lung has undergone pneumonectomy. During the procedure blackish hilar lymph node of 1 cm is seen. What is the etiology of the nodal pigmentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anthracotic pigment

 

Option A:

Presence of squamous cell cancer is associated with exposure to smoking and air pollution. This causes deposition of black colored pigment in the lung.

Robbins “Pulmonary anthracosis is the most innocuous coal-induced pulmonary lesion in coal miners and also is commonly seen in urban dwellers and tobacco smokers”.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. This represents iron deposition, typically brownish, and is associated with conditions involving hemorrhage or excessive iron, not the pigmentation seen in this case.

 

Option C. Known as the "wear and tear" pigment, lipofuscin accumulates in aging cells but does not cause the blackish pigmentation typical of anthracosis.

 

Option D. Melanin is a brown to black pigment produced by melanocytes. While melanin is responsible for the pigmentation of the skin and other tissues, it is not related to the pigmentation seen in the lungs related to smoking or pollution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anthracotic pigment is responsible for the blackish coloration of the hilar lymph node seen in the patient, associated with the history of lung squamous cell carcinoma, smoking, or exposure to air pollution.

choices.text: Bilirubin
Haptoglobin
Hemoglobin
Hemosiderin

questions.text: A middle aged man 45-year-old man presents with increasing abdominal girth and yellow discoloration of his skin and sclera. He had hepatomegaly and jaundice on physical examination. A Prussian blue stain of a liver biopsy is shown in the image. What is the major intracellular iron storage protein in this patient’s hepatocytes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemosiderin

 

Option D:

The history is suggestive of a disorder of iron metabolism specially iron overload called hemochromatosis. So, patients had a liver biopsy showing positive reaction with Prussian blue and hence the answer is “d”.

Hemosiderin is an iron storage complex found within cells, and its accumulation within hepatocytes, indicated by Prussian blue staining, is characteristic of iron overload conditions such as hemochromatosis.

 

Explanation:

Option A. Bilirubin is a breakdown product of hemoglobin and is not a storage form of iron.

Option B. Haptoglobin binds free hemoglobin released from erythrocytes, not iron directly, and is not a storage protein for iron within cells.

Option C. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein found in red blood cells, not an iron storage protein in hepatocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

Hemosiderin, is the major iron storage complex within cells. Its accumulation, indicated by Prussian blue staining in a liver biopsy, is indicative of iron overload and is commonly seen in conditions like hemochromatosis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 65

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus and joint pains presents with skin hyperpigmentation and elevated serum ferritin. A liver biopsy is performed, and the resulting slide is shown. The patient's liver biopsy is notable for a blue staining pattern within the hepatocytes. Given below is the histopathology of liver biopsy of a patient with hemochromatosis. Which of the following stain has been used?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prussian blue

 

Option A:

 

This iron stain, also known as Perls' Prussian blue, detects ferric iron by turning it blue. It is specifically used for the detection of iron overload in tissues, as seen in hemochromatosis.

 

Explanation

 

Option B: Alcian blue: Alcian blue stains acidic polysaccharides and glycosaminoglycans in tissues blue, which is used to identify mucopolysaccharides. It is not used for iron staining.

 

Option C: Von Kossa: The Von Kossa stain is used to detect calcium salts, which appear black under microscopy. This would not be the appropriate stain for identifying iron deposits in the liver.

 

Option D: Crystal violet: Crystal violet is a basic dye that stains the components of cells purple or blue-violet and is often used in Gram staining of bacteria. It is not used for the detection of iron in tissue samples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This stain is used to detect iron deposits in tissues and is characteristic of the pathology seen in hemochromatosis, where iron accumulation occurs within the hepatocytes.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 849

questions.text: Post mortem brain of a 90-year-old male with Alzheimer disease is shown in the image. All of the following are correct about the cellular process responsible for his condition except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased autophagic vacuoles

 

Option A:

 

There is an INCREASE of AUTOPHAGIC vacuoles in atrophy. There is an INCREASE in autophagic VACUOLES, into which LYSOSOMES DISCHARGE their hydrolytic contents.

 

Atrophy results from decreased protein synthesis and increased protein degradation in cells. The degradation of cellular proteins occurs mainly by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway.

 

Atrophy is also accompanied by increased autophagy, marked by the appearance of increased numbers of autophagic vacuoles. Some of the cell debris within the autophagic vacuoles may resist digestion and persist in the cytoplasm as membrane-bound residual bodies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Atrophy is characterized by SHRINKAGE and LOSS of structural ELEMENTS of cells (like myofilaments, ER).

 

Option C. Decreased smooth endoplasmic reticulum is seen in atrophy

 

Option D. Some cell debris resists digestion, and they persist as membrane bound residual bodies in cytoplasm (e.g., Lipofuscin granules).

 

Educational objective:

 

In the context of cellular atrophy, such as seen in Alzheimer's disease, there is an increase, not a decrease, in autophagic vacuoles as cells attempt to degrade damaged proteins and organelles.

 

Summary Table:

 

 

Ref:- Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed PG: 59

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffers a heart attack and expires. Examination of his cardiac tissue reveals the finding as shown in the image. The pigment in the image represents which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wear and tear pigment

 

Option A:

 

Wear and tear pigment: This option refers to lipofuscin, an aging pigment that accumulates as a result of free radical injury and lipid peroxidation within cells. It is a sign of the cell's past activity and is often found in long-lived cells, such as neurons and cardiac myocytes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fat deposits:  Fat deposits in the heart could suggest a lipid disorder or myocardial steatosis but typically appear as clear vacuoles within the cells, not as the dark, granular pigment seen in the image.

 

Option C. Blood pigment : Hemosiderin, the storage form of iron, can accumulate in tissues following hemorrhage or excessive iron intake, presenting as a golden-yellow to brown pigment, which is different in appearance from the pigment seen here.

 

Option D. Form of calcification: Calcification in tissues appears as basophilic (blue-purple) stippling or clumps within tissues on histology, which does not match the pigment observed in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lipofuscin, the pigment seen in the cardiac tissue of the patient who suffered a heart attack, is indicative of free radical damage and is not harmful to cell function.

 

 

Ref Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed PG: 65

choices.text: It may be caused by multiple myeloma
Calcium deposition occurs in dead tissues

questions.text: Regarding dystrophic calcification, which of the following statements is CORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Calcium deposition occurs in dead tissues

 

Option D:

 

Dystrophic calcification specifically occurs in dead or dying tissues and is typically seen in areas of necrosis, regardless of the serum calcium level.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It may be caused by multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma itself does not cause dystrophic calcification. However, it can lead to systemic changes that result in pathologic calcifications. Dystrophic calcification is specifically associated with local tissue damage and necrosis, not directly with plasma cell disorders like multiple myeloma.

 

Option B. It never causes organ dysfunction: This statement is incorrect. While dystrophic calcification occurs in non-viable tissues, it can interfere with organ function depending on the size and location of the calcifications.

 

Option C. It is associated with hypercalcaemia: Dystrophic calcification can occur despite normal serum levels of calcium. It is not typically associated with hypercalcemia, which is more commonly linked with metastatic calcification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dystrophic calcification is the deposition of calcium salts in non-viable or dying tissues and can occur with normal serum calcium levels, often leading to organ dysfunction if extensive.

 

Dystrophic calcification:

 

  • Calcium deposits in dead, dying, or damaged tissues.
  • Occurs despite normal serum calcium and phosphate levels.
  • Typical sites:
    • Old scars
    • Atherosclerotic plaques
    • Areas of caseous necrosis (e.g., TB)
    • Aging or damaged heart valves

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed PG: 59

choices.text: It rarely causes dysfunction
It does not occur on heart valves
It is formed by crystalline calcium phosphate
It is specific to coagulative necrosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the type of calcification in the image from a patient with papillary thyroid carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is formed by crystalline calcium phosphate

 

Option C:

 

It is formed by crystalline calcium phosphate. The image shows Psammoma bodies. It is a type of dystrophic calcification.

This is correct. Psammoma bodies are laminated, concentric, calcific spherules formed by crystalline calcium phosphate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It rarely causes dysfunction: This is incorrect, because Psammoma bodies, while sometimes incidental findings, can be associated with tumor progression and thus potential organ dysfunction, depending on their location and the underlying pathology.

 

Option B. It does not occur on heart valves: Psammoma bodies are not typically found on heart valves; instead, this option may confuse dystrophic calcification with the calcific degeneration that can occur in heart valves due to different pathophysiological processes.

 

Option D. It is specific to coagulative necrosis: Psammoma bodies are not specific to coagulative necrosis. They can be seen in various types of necrosis and in conditions unrelated to necrosis, such as certain tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psammoma bodies are calcifications seen in association with certain tumors, including papillary thyroid carcinoma, papillary renal cancer, meningioma and serous cystadenoma of the ovary.

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed PG: 59

questions.text: Which of the following is a preferred site for metastatic calcification?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastric mucosa

 

Option B:

 

Metastatic calcification occurs in NORMAL tissues and is associated with a RAISED SERUM calcium. The main causes include

 

  • Increased PTH

  • Destruction of bone

  • Vit D related disorders

  • Renal failure

 

Metastatic calcification can occur in the gastric mucosa due to the tissue’s ability to excrete acid, creating an alkaline environment that predisposes it to the deposition of calcium, especially when serum calcium levels are elevated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atherosclerotic vessels: These typically exhibit dystrophic calcification rather than metastatic. Dystrophic calcification occurs in damaged or necrotic tissues and does not necessarily involve a systemic mineral imbalance.

 

Option C. Damaged heart valves: Damaged heart valves are more prone to dystrophic calcification because of the local tissue damage, rather than metastatic calcification which occurs in normal tissues.

 

Option D. Tuberculous lymph nodes: Tuberculous lymph nodes would typically have dystrophic calcification due to the localized damage caused by the infection rather than metastatic calcification which is usually related to an abnormal systemic calcium or phosphorus metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metastatic calcification preferably occurs in normal tissues, like the gastric mucosa, when there is an elevated serum calcium level due to conditions such as hyperparathyroidism, bone destruction, vitamin D disorders, or renal failure.

 

Classic sites: 

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed - Pg:66,67

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented sudden onset hemiplegia. Serial investigations were performed. She was diagnosed with psammomatous meningioma, a subtype of meningioma with several psammoma bodies. Similar type of calcification can be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atheromatous plaque

 

Option B:

 

Psamomma bodies are associated with dystrophic calcification. Among the given options the other condition associated is atheromatous plaque.

 

This is the correct option. Atheromatous plaque, as seen in atherosclerosis, often contains areas of dystrophic calcification. This type of calcification occurs in the degenerated areas of the vessel walls where the plaques are located.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Milk alkali syndrome:  This condition is associated with hypercalcemia and not typically with dystrophic calcification. It results from excessive intake of calcium and absorbable alkali, leading to a constellation of symptoms including renal failure, metabolic alkalosis, and high levels of calcium in the blood.

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: Hyperparathyroidism leads to hypercalcemia and can result in metastatic calcification, which occurs in normal tissues, not specifically in areas of necrosis or degeneration like dystrophic calcification.

 

Option D. Vitamin A intoxication:  While vitamin A intoxication can lead to a wide range of systemic effects, it is not directly linked with dystrophic calcification, which is localized to areas of tissue damage or necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dystrophic calcification is a type of pathological calcification that occurs in dead, dying, or degenerated tissue, where calcium metabolism is typically normal, and serum calcium levels are unchanged. This type of calcification can be observed in atheromatous plaques as well as in psammomatous meningiomas.

 

Psammoma bodies:

 

  • Psammoma bodies are round, concentric, laminated calcific structures.
  • They form by dystrophic calcification:
    • Deposition of calcium in degenerating, dead, or dying cells/tissue.
    • Serum calcium is normal.
  • Characteristically seen in:
    • Psammomatous meningioma
    • Papillary carcinoma of thyroid
    • Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of ovary
    • Sometimes mesothelioma and other papillary tumors.

 

Dystrophic vs. metastatic calcification:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed - Pg:65,66

choices.text: Actin
Intermediate filaments
Microtubules

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth and decreased liver span. Liver biopsy features hepatocytes with reddish inclusions. What is in the content of the inclusions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intermediate filaments

 

Option B:

 

Mallory-Denk bodies are comprised of intermediate filaments, specifically ubiquitinylated keratins 8 and 18. These proteins form a dense network of filaments within the hepatocytes.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Actin: Actin is a component of the cytoskeleton involved in various types of cell motility but is not the primary component of the reddish inclusions found in hepatocytes, which are characteristic of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Option C. Microtubules: Microtubules are part of the cytoskeleton and are involved in maintaining cell shape and intracellular transport but are not the substance that composes the reddish inclusions seen in this patient's liver biopsy.

 

Option D. Fibronectin is an extracellular matrix protein that plays a critical role in wound healing and cell adhesion. It is not typically found within hepatocyte inclusions like Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reddish inclusions found within hepatocytes on a liver biopsy of a chronic alcoholic patient are composed of intermediate filaments, specifically ubiquitinated keratins 8 and 18, characteristic of Mallory-Denk bodies.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in given below image:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lipofuscin granules

 

Option A:

 

Lipofuscin is identified in the electron microscopy by its perinuclear and intralysosomal location.

 

Lipofuscin granules: These are intracellular, pigment-containing residual bodies of lysosomal origin that tend to accumulate with age. They are often located near the nucleus and have a distinctive granular appearance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Golgi apparatus: This is an organelle involved in the modification, sorting, and packaging of proteins, but it does not have the granular appearance shown in the image.

 

Option C. Secondary lysosomes: These are the organelles where digestion of macromolecules occurs. Secondary lysosomes can contain a variety of digested material, but they do not match the specific appearance of the structures shown.

 

Option D. Mitochondria: These are organelles responsible for ATP production and have a distinctive double membrane and cristae, which are not depicted in the image provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lipofuscin granules are identified in electron microscopy by their characteristic granular appearance, perinuclear position, and intralysosomal location, which align with the structures in the image.

 

Lipofuscin granules (also called residual bodies)

 

  • Origin: Lipofuscin is an autofluorescent pigment derived from lipid peroxidation of subcellular membranes; it accumulates in lysosomes as a product of incomplete degradation.
  • Appearance on EM:
    • Irregular in shape, not perfectly round.
    • Electron-dense (dark) with a heterogeneous internal structure.
    • May show whorled lamellar or granular material.
    • Often clustered near the nucleus (perinuclear).
  • Clinical context:
    • Common in long-lived cells (e.g., neurons, cardiac myocytes, hepatocytes).
    • Called “wear-and-tear” pigment because it accumulates with age.
  • Key point:
    • Because lipofuscin is undegradable material, it remains as residual bodies in the cell cytoplasm, separate from active digestion.

choices.text: Accumulation of lipid in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes
Accumulation of glycogen in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes
Accumulation of iron in the hepatic parenchyma
Accumulation of iron in the Kupffer cells.

questions.text: A 40-year obese non-alcoholic female presented with mild right sided abdominal pain. Examination was normal. Blood work revealed mild increase in liver enzymes (SGOT and SGPT) with normal Total Bilirubin and direct bilirubin. Ultrasonography performed revealed few hyperechoic regions in the liver. If a biopsy is performed, which finding will most likely be seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of lipid in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes.

 

Option A:

This is a case of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Accumulation of lipids in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes is characteristic. This is also observed in alcoholic liver disease.

Fatty changes occur in alcoholic steatosis (fatty liver).

It is manifested by appearance of lipid vacuole in the cytoplasm, which is   a sign of reversible injury.

Given the non-alcoholic status and ultrasound findings, lipid accumulation within hepatocytes is characteristic of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. While glycogen accumulation can occur in diabetes and glycogen storage diseases, it is less likely given the ultrasound findings and clinical presentation.

 

Option C. Iron accumulation is seen in conditions such as hemochromatosis but is not typically associated with the clinical picture described, which suggests NAFLD.

 

Option D. Iron accumulation within Kupffer cells may occur secondary to certain conditions but is not indicative of NAFLD, the likely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The expected histological finding in a biopsy of a patient with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is the accumulation of lipid within hepatocyte cytoplasm. This condition is characterized by elevated liver enzymes and the presence of fatty infiltrates on imaging.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed (Latest)- Pg: 37
